text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full-width miniature framed by a pink-and-white geometric meander border, positioned within the text block with one line of vernacular Old French text above. The illustration occupies the column width, creating a clear visual break between textual passages, with generous margins around the image emphasizing its importance.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with decorative flourishes and consistent use of diamond-shaped serifs

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf used for the stylized ground and crowns to denote divine wrath and royal power; vermilion reserved for the multi-headed dragon and flaming tongues as symbols of evil; ultramarine blue provides a celestial backdrop associated with the heavens; white lead highlights model halos and small decorative dots; black ink outlines define forms and details.

features: Large central beast dominates left field
Diagonal movement from dragon’s tail toward crowned woman
Layered ground line of gold pattern
Balanced weight: massive beast on left countered by mounted woman on right

decorative_elements: Pink-and-white geometric meander border framing the scene

drawing_technique.line_style: Bold black-ink outlines with fluid quill pen strokes, varying line weight to emphasize contours
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color areas with minimal tonal gradation, white lead used for highlights on robes and halos
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without linear perspective, depth suggested by overlapping figures and ground line

content_theme.scene_description: A single apocalyptic vision occupies the miniature. On the left, a vast seven-headed red dragon with gold crowns on each head stands upon a stylized golden ground. Its tongues of flame, rendered in red with gold spines, arc over the scene. In the center foreground five haloed figures kneel in prayer: two clerics with tonsures in gray and green robes, and three lay worshippers in red and green mantles. Their hands are clasped before their chests; one cleric holds a small book. To the right a crowned woman, the Whore of Babylon, sits astride a smaller red beast with goat-like horns. She wears a gold crown and layered gown of green and red, holding a slender staff. The beasts’ claws rest on the golden ground line, and a star-dotted ultramarine sky fills the background. Figures overlap to suggest depth; the dragon’s tail curves behind the kneelers, linking left and right visually.

religious: Five haloed worshippers (tonsured cleric in gray robe, lay figures in red and green mantles)
symbolic: Crowned woman (Whore of Babylon) in layered gown, mounted on beast

natural: Stylized rocky ground patterned in gold leaf
Starry ultramarine sky with white-lead stars

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum with a smooth, well-pumiced surface; regular quaternion gatherings with ca. 2 cm margins visible around the miniature
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments remain vivid with minimal flaking; gold leaf shows slight abrasion along edges; very light cockling at folio corners; evidence of early modern stabilization on lower margin
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf creating subtle relief
Regular plummet ruling visible beneath image
Confident underdrawing detectable under UV light

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Noble individual engaged in personal prayer and meditation

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature of the Whore of Babylon appears in a vernacular Old French Apocalypse produced in a mid-14th-century Parisian workshop. The use of ultramarine and burnished gold leaf reflects access to luxury materials, suggesting a noble patron’s commission for private devotion. The geometric meander border aligns with decorative conventions of the Parisian School, while the flat application of color and bold outlines demonstrate continuity with earlier Gothic illumination. The depiction of the seven-headed dragon crowned to signify its diabolic power, and the female figure astride the beast, directly illustrates Revelation 17:3–5, underlining the moral and theological program condemning ecclesiastical corruption. Technically, the layered pigments and raised gesso indicate advanced material practice, while the clear plummet rulings reveal a methodical planning stage. Iconographically, the miniature serves as both warning and mnemonic device, reflecting late medieval eschatological anxieties and the patron’s concern with spiritual vigilance. Comparatively, its stylistic vocabulary resonates with the Apocalypse of Charles V (BnF fr. 403), yet the simplified gothic border and intimate scale point to a more personal devotional manuscript. Thus, the illumination bridges high-profile court commissions and private prayer books, combining traditional iconography with economical compositional innovation.
